user_message:
<misra_rule>
The target MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8 is: A function parameter should not be modified.
Note that the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified.
</misra_rule>
<instruction>
Other agents will judge whether the code follows the MISRA C 2023 guidelines.
They will investigate the code fragments you give.
Your job is to find code fragments in the code that should be investigated to check whether the code follows the MISRA C rule.
</instruction>
<response format>
Provide your answer with these fields.
- suspicious_frags: The list of suspicious code fragments in the code.
It should contain only the code fragments exists in the code. If you do not find any suspicious code fragments, return an empty list for suspicious_frags
- explanation: The explanation of why other code fragments should NOT be investigated.
It is very important to not miss any suspicious code fragments, so please give a sufficient explanation why other code fragments should not be investigated.
DO NOT give any explanation for the selected suspicious code fragments.
</response format>
<target_code>
Here is the code of answer_unique_dyn_response:
```c
static enum MHD_Result
answer_unique_dyn_response (void *cls,
                            struct MHD_Connection *connection,
                            const char *url,
                            const char *method,
                            const char *version,
                            const char *upload_data,
                            size_t *upload_data_size,
                            void **req_cls)
{
  static int marker = 0;
  struct MHD_Response *r;
  enum MHD_Result ret;
  (void) cls;  /* Unused */
  (void) url; (void) version; /* Unused */
  (void) upload_data; (void) upload_data_size; /* Unused */

  if (NULL == *req_cls)
  {
    /* The fist call */
    *req_cls = (void *) ▮
    /* Do not send reply yet. No error. */
    return MHD_YES;
  }
  if ((0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_GET)) &&
      (0 != strcmp (method, MHD_HTTP_METHOD_HEAD)))
    return MHD_NO; /* Unsupported method, close connection */

#if MHD_VERSION >= 0x00097701
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer_static (body_dyn_size,
                                              body_dyn);
#else  /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  r = MHD_create_response_from_buffer (body_dyn_size,
                                       (void *) body_dyn,
                                       MHD_RESPMEM_PERSISTENT);
#endif /* MHD_VERSION < 0x00097701 */
  ret = MHD_queue_response (connection, MHD_HTTP_OK, r);
  MHD_destroy_response (r);
  return ret;
}
```
</target_code>
Please find suspicious code fragments in the code and report them. Other agents can not investigate other fragments that you do not report, so it is very important to find all suspicious fragments without missing any. Report the suspicious fragments AS MUCH AS POSSIBLE.
explanation:
No function parameter is modified in this function. Specifically:
- There are no assignments to any parameter variables (e.g. cls, connection, url, method, version, upload_data, upload_data_size, req_cls). The only assignment present is to *req_cls ("*req_cls = (void *)▮"), which modifies the object pointed to by the pointer parameter req_cls — this is explicitly permitted by Rule 17.8 (the object referred to by a pointer parameter may be modified, but the pointer itself shall not be modified).
- The (void) parameter casts (e.g. (void) cls; (void) url; (void) upload_data_size;) merely mark parameters as unused and do not modify them.
- Other uses of parameters are read-only (e.g. comparison of method via strcmp, passing connection to MHD_queue_response) and do not assign to the parameter variables.
- The casts to (void *) when calling the response creation function do not modify any function parameter.
Therefore, there are no code fragments that need investigation for a potential violation of MISRA C 2023 Rule 17.8.
